Maybe, just maybe, I could do this. Maybe I could be a good father to this little girl, even if Tom wasn't here to be one with me. en_results_raw: see how he managed to maintain such a charming facade, I found myself drawn into their circle on more than one occasion. His companion, a striking young woman with piercing green eyes and raven-black hair, seemed to be the center of attention wherever they went. She would laugh and smile, and the men around her would be smitten, but he would just smile and nod, as if to say, "I know a secret that you don't." It was almost as if he had a certain aura about him, a confidence that was infectious and drew people in. I watched as he effortlessly charmed a group of strangers, making them laugh and feel at ease, and I couldn't help but wonder what secrets he might be hiding behind that charming smile of his. As I observed him, I began to notice that he seemed to be searching for something, or someone, and I found myself wondering if it was the same thing that had brought him to this particular café on this particular evening. The atmosphere was lively, with the sounds of jazz music drifting through the air and the smell of freshly brewed coffee wafting from the kitchen, but amidst all the noise and commotion, I sensed a sense of unease emanating from him, a sense of restlessness that seemed to be growing by the minute. I couldn't help but feel that he was on the verge of something, but I had no idea what it might be, or what might happen next.

es_results_raw: en un bar oscuro y ruidoso, rodeado de personas que parecían conocerlo bien, pero que no parecían muy interesadas en su conversación. El hombre bebía un trago de su vaso de whisky, luego se volvió hacia el barman y le pidió otro, mientras que sus ojos se movían rápidamente alrededor del local, como si estuviera buscando algo o a alguien. La música era alegre y la atmósfera era animada, pero el hombre parecía estar en un mundo aparte, perdido en sus pensamientos y preocupaciones. Su expresión era seria y preocupada, y su cuerpo se movía con un ritmo lento y pesado, como si estuviera luchando contra una fuerza invisible. El barman le sirvió otro trago y el hombre lo aceptó con un gesto brusco, sin decir una palabra. Luego, se volvió hacia la pared y se quedó mirando fijamente un cuadro que colgaba en la pared, sin parecer verlo en absoluto. Su mente parecía estar en otro lugar, y su cuerpo parecía estar en una lucha constante contra la realidad. La noche era joven y la noche era larga, y el hombre parecía estar en el centro de un torbellino de pensamientos y emociones que lo llevaban a lugares oscuros y desconocidos.

en_first_half: Once I wrote down on the empty spaces of a timetable the names of those who came to Gatsby’s house that summer. It is an old timetable now, disintegrating at its folds, and headed “This schedule in effect July
en_second_half: 5th, 1922.” But I can still read the grey names, and they will give you a better impression than my generalities of those who accepted Gatsby’s hospitality and paid him the subtle tribute of knowing nothing whatever about him.
en_results: was drawn up by me in the spring of nineteen twenty-one, when the war was over and the great romantic epoch was beginning. It was a time of reckless abandon and carefree joy, a time when the world seemed full of endless possibilities
en_results_raw: was drawn up by me in the spring of nineteen twenty-one, when the war was over and the great romantic epoch was beginning. It was a time of reckless abandon and carefree joy, a time when the world seemed full of endless possibilities and the future seemed bright. The names of those who came to Gatsby's house that summer were etched on the timetable in bold, black ink, a testament to the excitement and anticipation that filled the air. There was Daisy, the golden girl of the Valley of Ashes, with her porcelain skin and her voice like honey. There was Tom, her husband, with his brutish charm and his cruel smile. And then there were the others, the ones who came to Gatsby's parties, the ones who danced and laughed and loved in the warm summer nights. They were a diverse group, a mix of old money and new, of old friends and new acquaintances, all united by their desire to escape the mundane routine of everyday life and lose themselves in the magic of the summer. As I looked at the timetable, I couldn't help but feel a sense of nostalgia wash over me, a sense of longing for a time that could never be recaptured. The names on the timetable seemed to whisper secrets to me, secrets of a summer that was long gone, but still lingered in my memory like a ghost. The timetable itself was old and worn, its pages yellowed with age, but the memories it held were still vivid and alive, a testament to the power of human connection and the enduring magic of the human spirit.

El olor a comida callejera y a humo de cigarro se mezclaba con el olor a sal del mar, y el aire estaba cargado de la emoción de la multitud que se preparaba para la fiesta de la noche. La ciudad parecía estar a punto de estallar en una explosión de color y sonido, y yo sentía mi corazón latir con la misma emoción que la multitud. La calle principal se estrechaba y se volvía cada vez más oscura, y nos acercábamos a la parte más antigua de la ciudad, donde las calles eran estrechas y sin asfalto, y los edificios parecían tener siglos de historia en sus paredes. La gente se apretujaba en las esquinas, hablando en voz baja y mirando hacia arriba, hacia las ventanas de los edificios altos, donde las luces brillaban como estrellas en la oscuridad. El ruido de la multitud se hacía cada vez más fuerte, y yo sentía que estaba a punto de perder el control, de ser arrastrado por la emoción de la multitud. We passed by the lake, where children were playing and laughing together, their joyful shouts carrying through the air. As we continued our drive, the sounds of the city began to fade, replaced by the peaceful sounds of nature. The park was a tranquil oasis in the midst of the bustling metropolis, and I felt my worries slowly start to unravel as we glided along the winding path. The driver, a kind-eyed old man with a bushy mustache, seemed to sense my relaxation and smiled to himself, his eyes twinkling with amusement. We rode in silence for a while, the only sound being the soft clip-clop of the horses' hooves on the pavement. The trees grew taller and the air grew cooler as we made our way deeper into the park, the sun's warmth giving way to a gentle breeze that rustled the leaves of the trees. As we turned a corner, I caught a glimpse of the city skyline in the distance, a reminder that even in this peaceful haven, the hustle and bustle of the world was never far away.

es_first_half: En lugar de tomar el atajo de la costa bajamos a la carretera y entramos por la gran cancela. Con susurros encantadores Daisy admiró este o aquel aspecto de la silueta feudal con el cielo como fondo, admiró los jardines, el olor chispeante de los junquillos, el burbujeante olor de
es_second_half: los espinos y de los ciruelos en flor, y el pálido olor a oro de la milamores. Era extraño llegar a la escalinata de mármol y no encontrar un revuelo de vestidos radiantes, entrando y saliendo de la casa, y sólo oír el canto de los pájaros en los árboles.
es_results: el perfume de las flores silvestres, el sonido de los pájaros cantando en los árboles altos y el murmullo de la fuente que se encontraba en el centro del jardín. Al llegar a la entrada principal, nos recibió un mayordomo con un gesto elegante, que nos condujo
es_results_raw: el perfume de las flores silvestres, el sonido de los pájaros cantando en los árboles altos y el murmullo de la fuente que se encontraba en el centro del jardín. Al llegar a la entrada principal, nos recibió un mayordomo con un gesto elegante, que nos condujo a través de un pasillo largo y oscuro hasta llegar a la gran sala de recepción. Allí nos esperaba el dueño de la casa, un anciano con una sonrisa amable y un brillo en los ojos que parecía esconder un secreto. Se presentó como el señor Edward, y con un gesto cortés nos invitó a sentarnos en el sofá, mientras él se sentaba en su silla de respaldo alto, con una actitud que parecía indicar que estaba a punto de compartir con nosotros un secreto importante. Mientras tanto, Daisy no podía apartar la mirada de las pinturas que adornaban las paredes, que parecían contar historias de amor y tristeza, de pasión y muerte. El señor Edward, notando su interés, se acercó a ella y comenzó a contarle la historia detrás de cada una de las pinturas, con una voz que parecía transportarla a un mundo de fantasía y magia. Y así, mientras escuchaba las historias del señor Edward, Daisy se sintió como si estuviera viviendo en un cuento de hadas, rodeada de un mundo de belleza y misterio.

en_first_half: It was like that. Almost the last thing I remember was standing with Daisy and watching the moving-picture director and his Star. They were still under the white-plum tree and their faces were touching except for a pale, thin
en_second_half: ray of moonlight between. It occurred to me that he had been very slowly bending toward her all evening to attain this proximity, and even while I watched I saw him stoop one ultimate degree and kiss at her cheek.
en_results: The sky was painted with hues of orange and pink as the sun dipped below the horizon, casting a warm glow over the entire scene. Daisy's eyes sparkled with a mix of sadness and longing as she gazed at the director,
en_results_raw: The sky was painted with hues of orange and pink as the sun dipped below the horizon, casting a warm glow over the entire scene. Daisy's eyes sparkled with a mix of sadness and longing as she gazed at the director, her voice barely above a whisper as she spoke to him. The director, a man in his mid-forties with a kind face and a twinkle in his eye, listened intently, his expression a mask of understanding and empathy. The Star, a young woman with a porcelain complexion and raven-black hair, stood frozen in place, her eyes fixed on some point beyond the director's shoulder. The air was heavy with unspoken emotions, the only sound the distant hum of crickets and the soft rustle of leaves in the gentle breeze. As the director finally spoke, his words were like a gentle breeze on a summer's day, soothing and calming, but also tinged with a hint of melancholy. Daisy's eyes never left his face, her expression a picture of hope and longing, as if she was searching for something in his words, something that only he could provide. The Star, on the other hand, seemed lost in thought, her eyes fixed on some distant point, her face a mask of serenity, but with a hint of turmoil lurking beneath the surface. The scene was one of quiet introspection, a moment of pause in the midst of chaos, a moment of connection between three people who were bound together by their shared experiences and emotions.

en_results_raw: the desolate, yet somehow familiar landscape of his own backyard, he felt a sense of resignation wash over him. The once vibrant flowers that had bloomed with such promise just a few short months ago now stood wilted and brown, their petals scattered about like the remnants of a forgotten party. The sky above was a dull gray, a reflection of the emptiness that had settled within him. He took a deep breath, the cool morning air filling his lungs, and began to walk towards the old oak tree, its branches creaking in the gentle breeze. The sound was a reminder that life still went on, even in the face of loss. As he approached the tree, he noticed a small bird perched on a branch, its song a melancholic melody that seemed to echo the sorrow that had taken up residence within him. He stood there for a moment, frozen in time, as the bird's song washed over him, a poignant reminder of the transience of life and the inevitability of death. The bird's song faded away, and Mr. Gatz was left standing there, lost in thought, his eyes fixed on the spot where his loved one had last been seen. The silence that followed was oppressive, a heavy blanket that wrapped itself around him, weighing him down with the weight of his grief. He took another deep breath, the sound of his own ragged breathing the only sound that broke the stillness. And in that moment, he knew that he had to keep moving forward, no matter how difficult it may be, for it was the only way to honor the memory of those who had been lost.

La gente caminaba con paso lento y triste, como si estuvieran sumidas en sus propios pensamientos, y las luces de las casas parecían apagadas, como si la vida misma hubiera sido apagada. El río, que había sido testigo de tantas noches de fiesta y diversión, ahora parecía estar llorando, sus aguas negras y turbulentas como si estuvieran reflejando la tristeza que se había apoderado de la ciudad. La gente hablaba en susurros, como si no quisiera despertar a la ciudad de su letargo, y los periódicos hablaban de la muerte de Gatsby como si fuera un evento que había cambiado el curso de la historia. en_second_half: sea to sweep my refuse away. I saw Jordan Baker and talked over and around what had happened to us together, and what had happened afterward to me, and she lay perfectly still, listening, in a big chair.
en_results: The housekeeper, Mrs. Jenkins, had been acting strangely all morning, and I couldn't shake the feeling that she knew more than she was letting on. I decided to clear the air and have a word with her before
en_results_raw: The housekeeper, Mrs. Jenkins, had been acting strangely all morning, and I couldn't shake the feeling that she knew more than she was letting on. I decided to clear the air and have a word with her before I left. I found her in the kitchen, busily washing dishes and humming a tune, but her eyes sparkled with a hint of knowing when she saw me. I approached her and cleared my throat to get her attention, and then I asked her if she had seen anything unusual lately. She paused, her hands still submerged in the soapy water, and I could sense a hesitation before she spoke. "Unusual?" she repeated, her voice neutral, but her eyes told a different story. I pressed her for an answer, and she finally relented, her words spilling out in a rush. "It's just that there have been some... noises at night," she said, her voice barely above a whisper. "Doors creaking, footsteps in the hallway, that sort of thing. I've tried to ignore it, but it's been going on for weeks now, and I'm starting to get a bit spooked." I listened intently, my mind racing with possibilities, and then I asked her if she had noticed anything else. She hesitated again, and I could see the fear lurking behind her eyes. "There's something else," she said, her voice trembling slightly. "I've seen... things. Shadows, I suppose you'd call them. Moving around the house, especially in the attic. I know it sounds silly, but I've tried to convince myself it's just my imagination, but deep down, I know it's something more." I thanked her for her honesty and promised to look into it, but I couldn't shake the feeling that we were just scratching the surface of something much bigger and more sinister. As I left the house, I couldn't help but wonder what other secrets lay hidden beneath the surface, waiting to be uncovered.
